Issues.Title: `--config remote` and `--config debug` are incompatible
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> The issue is caused by `yarn bazel`


### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> I don't know, I've never tried this before.


### Description

<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> I had `build --config remote` in my `.bazelrc.user` which I added a long time ago for RBE. Today I needed to debug a test and was pointed at `--config debug`. When I tried to use it however, I immediately got an error that the test timeout was too long:

```
$ yarn bazel test --config debug //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc
yarn run v1.22.4
$ /home/douglasparker/Source/ng/node_modules/.bin/bazel test --config debug //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc
INFO: Invocation ID: ef001969-b478-4b86-994d-db49c0031214
WARNING: Streamed test output requested. All tests will be run locally, without sharding, one at a time
INFO: Build options --crosstool_top, --define, --extra_execution_platforms, and 8 more have changed, discarding analysis cache.
DEBUG: /home/douglasparker/.cache/bazel/_bazel_douglasparker/aef1a2fc4785727e712f458c2fbf89e6/external/bazel_toolchains/rules/rbe_repo.bzl:491:10: Bazel 3.2.0 is used in rbe_ubuntu1604_angular.
WARNING: /home/douglasparker/.cache/bazel/_bazel_douglasparker/aef1a2fc4785727e712f458c2fbf89e6/external/remote_java_tools_linux/BUILD:671:11: in hdrs attribute of cc_library rule @remote_java_tools_linux//:combiners: Artifact 'external/remote_java_tools_linux/java_tools/src/tools/singlejar/zip_headers.h' is duplicated (through '@remote_java_tools_linux//:transient_bytes' and '@remote_java_tools_linux//:zip_headers'). Since this rule was created by the macro 'cc_library', the error might have been caused by the macro implementation
INFO: Analyzed target //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc:ngtsc (7 packages loaded, 5022 targets configured).
INFO: Found 1 test target...
ERROR: /home/douglasparker/Source/ng/packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc/BUILD.bazel:24:18: Couldn't build file packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc/ngtsc/test.log:  failed (Exit 34): INVALID_ARGUMENT: Invalid arguments: 
  "action.timeout": Timeout 2h46m39s exceeds maximum timeout of 1h0m0s. Note: Remote connection/protocol failed with: execution failed INVALID_ARGUMENT: Invalid arguments: 
  "action.timeout": Timeout 2h46m39s exceeds maximum timeout of 1h0m0s
Target //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc:ngtsc up-to-date:
  dist/bin/packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc/ngtsc.sh
  dist/bin/packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc/ngtsc_loader.js
  dist/bin/packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc/ngtsc_require_patch.js
INFO: Elapsed time: 26.685s, Critical Path: 24.02s
INFO: 46 processes: 44 remote cache hit, 2 remote.
FAILED: Build did NOT complete successfully
//packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc:ngtsc                              NO STATUS

FAILED: Build did NOT complete successfully
error Command failed with exit code 34.
info Visit https://yarnpkg.com/en/docs/cli/run for documentation about this command.
```

I updated the [`--config debug`](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/5a733629b531083fd35563ee5bc286a8954da5fc/.bazelrc#L2) definition to use `--test_timeout=3600` to avoid this error. After that however, the test just hangs. It does not execute and does not print out that it is waiting for a debugger.

```
$ yarn bazel test --config debug //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc
yarn run v1.22.4
$ /home/douglasparker/Source/ng/node_modules/.bin/bazel test --config debug //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc
INFO: Invocation ID: bd00ec13-83e3-44be-9198-e94cbba45ccb
WARNING: Streamed test output requested. All tests will be run locally, without sharding, one at a time
INFO: Build option --test_timeout has changed, discarding analysis cache.
DEBUG: /home/douglasparker/.cache/bazel/_bazel_douglasparker/aef1a2fc4785727e712f458c2fbf89e6/external/bazel_toolchains/rules/rbe_repo.bzl:491:10: Bazel 3.2.0 is used in rbe_ubuntu1604_angular.
WARNING: /home/douglasparker/.cache/bazel/_bazel_douglasparker/aef1a2fc4785727e712f458c2fbf89e6/external/remote_java_tools_linux/BUILD:671:11: in hdrs attribute of cc_library rule @remote_java_tools_linux//:combiners: Artifact 'external/remote_java_tools_linux/java_tools/src/tools/singlejar/zip_headers.h' is duplicated (through '@remote_java_tools_linux//:transient_bytes' and '@remote_java_tools_linux//:zip_headers'). Since this rule was created by the macro 'cc_library', the error might have been caused by the macro implementation
INFO: Analyzed target //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc:ngtsc (1 packages loaded, 5022 targets configured).
INFO: Found 1 test target...
[120 / 121] Testing //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc:ngtsc; 300s remote
```

It was some time before I realized the problem was `build --config remote` in my `.bazelrc.user` file.

I understand that debugging like this requires the test to be executed locally, so `--config remote` doesn't really apply. However, it is a really easy foot-gun that leads to some pretty unintuitive behavior. Ideally there would be a way to:

1. Make `--config debug` take precedence over `--config remote`.
    * I'm not sure exactly how this could work, but I guess any flags in `--config debug` would be **probably** win over `--config remote`, since the former is a command line flag while the later is from a `.bazelrc` file?
2. Warn or error when these two flags are used together.
    * Even less sure if this is possible. No idea exactly how that would work.

Hopefully there's some way we can catch this particular error without just having tests hang forever.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "`--config remote` and `--config debug` are incompatible" (#38187)

Issues.Title: Ivy LS: refactor type constructors and input binding checking
Issues.Body:
Currently input bindings in templates are type-checked via a type constructor call for the directive or component in question. This is mainly for convenience, since type constructors were always called with the inputs present anyway.

This is undesirable for two reasons:
1) Type constructors are expensive, and often unnecessary. They only need to be called if the directive or component is actually generic, and only need those inputs passed which reference the generic type parameters.

2) For language service use cases, it is valuable to have a direct assignment operation for inputs in the TCB in order to extract LS information (e.g. `ts.TypeChecker.getSymbolAtLocation`).

Thus, we should refactor the way input checking works:
* only call type constructors when necessary, and only with those inputs that affect generic type inference
* always emit assignment operations for inputs
* for diagnostics, rely on the type ctor call for generic inputs, and on the assignment operations for non-generic inputs (adding the ignore flag to the others)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Ivy LS: refactor type constructors and input binding checking" (#38185)

Issues.Title: What's a reasonable expectation of angular performance?
Issues.Body:
So my app is slow. That slow part consists of iteration over medium complex components with another bunch of nested components inside
![image](https://i.imgur.com/aoyc1er.png)

Trying to render more than one of these started to add up a LOT of scripting time, up to the point where trying to render 10 of them caused 30 second freeze. 

The first and biggest culprit I found was @angular/flex-layout, which, as you know, if you managed to click [deep enough](https://github.com/angular/flex-layout/wiki/Performance-Considerations) inside the wiki can not handle more than a hundred of grids (since I used it inside like 10 of the nested components inside it easily added up to that critical number).

But even still, with flex-layout completely gone, trying to render 100 of these can take around 12 seconds, so I thought there must be sometimes else wrong and tried to establish a baseline on a completely fresh project. That can be found here https://github.com/fxck/ngperf.

### Baseline
Iterating over 200 items, printing simple text.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88206816-2c8ad480-cc4f-11ea-985b-44441afba764.png)

That takes around **100ms** from click on the button to the content being visible.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88206895-4cba9380-cc4f-11ea-927e-4a40fa48ae3d.png)

### Baseline for complex tests
Iterating over 200 components with mat-card and ngClass inside
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88207043-7d023200-cc4f-11ea-81ca-0da3bebffe8d.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88207075-8ab7b780-cc4f-11ea-9e99-923fac814cc1.png)

That takes around **200ms** from click on the button to the content being visible.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88207131-a327d200-cc4f-11ea-841b-d7ce264a261a.png)

### Test 1
Adding 20 empty divs to complex baseline

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88207220-c6eb1800-cc4f-11ea-8442-7a25a65a61ca.png)

That takes around **250ms** from click on the button to the content being visible, most of the extra time taken by rendering, which makes sense.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88207323-e3875000-cc4f-11ea-953b-4fc7222a34d0.png)

### Test 2
Adding 20 divs with ngClass and ngStyle on them

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88207431-129dc180-cc50-11ea-849e-a8d5c2a441ba.png)

That takes around **400ms** from click on the button to the content being visible, extra time coming from scripting.. given that's total of like 4000 new ngClasses and ngStyles, 100ms extra time spent on scripting is fair I guess
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88207510-319c5380-cc50-11ea-9bbd-7acbea73360e.png)
 
### Test 3 
Adding 20 components with a single div with ngClass and ngStyle inside them

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88207807-9b1c6200-cc50-11ea-856c-b518ffc5085a.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88207841-a53e6080-cc50-11ea-8b99-64109d383bd7.png)

Now this takes around **900ms** from click on the button to the content being visible, 200 extra milliseconds coming rendering and another 200ms from scripting.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88207954-cdc65a80-cc50-11ea-8bfe-57661fa80f75.png)

The third one confuses me the most, why would it take double the amount of time between test 2 and test 3? That makes me question everything about splitting my app into many reusable component, if there's a huge performance hit like this.

Coming back around to my actual component (https://i.imgur.com/aoyc1er.png), it has quite a few nested components, most of them have multiple states, content projection, styles, classes, so seeing how much mess can an empty component create, how many can I possibly render at once before having to resort to infinite scroll strategies?

(both repro and my app uses v10)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88208529-a623c200-cc51-11ea-93c7-125d29d5088b.png)



---

btw this is what rendering 20 of those components looks like WITHOUT flex-layout

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88210283-3b27ba80-cc54-11ea-8329-723472062dff.png)

and WITH flex
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1303561/88210608-bf7a3d80-cc54-11ea-9524-9d8397f36fd4.png)

20 seconds of scripting time difference!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "What's a reasonable expectation of angular performance?" (#38184)

Issues.Title: Angular 8 - @angular/core has no exported member …µ…µFactoryDef, etc.
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package

@angular/core

### Is this a regression?

No.


### Description

I have created a custom Angular library using Angular 8. The issue occurs in @angular/core/core in that library.

When an Angular 9 project imports this library through `npm install`, and when I run `ng build` to build the Angular 9 project, I get errors similar to the following:

`@angular/core/core has no exported member …µ…µFactoryDef`

`@angular/core/src/r3_symbols has no exported member eeFactoryDef`

`@angular/core/src/r3_symbols has no exported member eeInjectableDef`

etc.

## üî• Exception or Error

See above in description.

## üåç  Your Environment

The Angular library that has the `@angular/core` errors is version 8.
The Angular project that uses the library is version 9.

A ticket for this issue has already been submitted [here](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/35291).

But there some issues with that. For one, [this comment](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/35291#issuecomment-585102857) says to run using `ng build --prod`, but the [Angular documentation](https://angular.io/cli/build) says that `ng build` automatically runs in production.

Then, [this comment](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/35291#issuecomment-586338571) says to delete `node_modules` folder and run `npm i`. I tried that and it didn't work.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Angular 8 - @angular/core has no exported member …µ…µFactoryDef, etc." (#38175)

Issues.Title: fix(dev-infra): ignore comments when validating commit messages
Issues.Body:
When creating a commit with the git cli, git pre-populates the editor used to enter the commit message with some comments (i.e. lines starting with `#`). These comments contain helpful instructions or information regarding the changes that are part of the commit. As happens with all commit message comments, they are removed by git and do not end up in the final commit message.

However, the file that is passed to the `commit-msg` to be validated still contains these comments. This may affect the outcome of the commit message validation. In such cases, the author will not realize that the commit message is not in the desired format until the linting checks fail on CI (which validates the final commit messages and is not affected by this issue), usually several minutes later.

Possible ways in which the commit message validation outcome can be affected:
- The minimum body length check may pass incorrectly, even if there is no actual body, because the comments are counted as part of the body.
- The maximum line length check may fail incorrectly due to a very long line in the comments.

This commit fixes the problem by removing comment lines before validating a commit message that comes from a file.

Fixes #37865.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(dev-infra): ignore comments when validating commit messages" (#38169)

Issues.Title: Unable to see source of Angular TS classes in IDE's (e.g. WebStorm or VS Code)
Issues.Body:
Hi :)

When using Angular it is very unfortunate that we cannot see the code behind the Angular TS classes. We can see the class declarations in WebStorm and VS Code but not the code behind the methods. It's only when debugging and setting breakpoints that the IDE¬¥s show the code behind the classes (they get it from the source maps).

So my question is: would it not be possible to create a set of Angular packages that embeds the class sources for Angular and not just the class declarations ? This would make it much easier to understand and debug the finer points og Angular and Angular components. 

The above also applies to the Angular Material components, it's not just the Angular core that is at issue here.

Yours
Christa :)

Issues.Title: refactor(dev-infra): update commit body checks
Issues.Body:
This commit updates the commit body checking logic:
* avoid checking the length of lines in commit body
* ignores lines that start with `#` char, since these lines are skipped by git
* adds `release` into the `minBodyLengthTypeExcludes` list in a config rather than having a hard-coded exclusion for this commit type in the code

Resolves #37865.

- [x] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

Issues.Title: docs: Refactor frequent-ngmodules.md to make it easier to understand
Issues.Body:
Project DOCS-735 to rewrite headings to focus on user tasks,
verify that the content is up-to-date and complete, and
add relevant links to other NgModule topics to improve readability.
Also addresses one of many issues in GitHub issue 21531.

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [x] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
<!-- Please describe the current behavior that you are modifying, or link to a relevant issue. -->

Issue Number: [21531](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/21531)
[Doc Plan: NgModule Section Doc Plan](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1QoRa8jBSyjf3Fpg7i7leA2iKL3ewEkLPgAo8V8SR1Bk/edit?usp=sharing)

Language is sometimes awkward.
Issue 21531: Doc suggests using the deprecated HttpModule to talk to a server, instead of using HttpClientModule.
Need to include content from [NgModule FAQ](https://angular.io/guide/ngmodule-faq#what-should-i-import).

## What is the new behavior?

Rewrote headings for better understanding.
Removed colloquial phrases.
Clarifies why frequently-used modules are useful and how to use them.
Changes the example to be embedded code from real example.
Clarifies the example.
Offers relevant hyperlinks to inform users (1) What they need to know for this topic to make sense and (2) What topics might be of interest after they finish reading

Include the following from NgModule FAQ:
  "What should I import?"
  "Should I import BrowserModule or CommonModule?"
  "What if I import the same module twice?"
Example is hard-coded.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information

Issues.Title: refactor(dev-infra): Add support for groups in the conditions evaluator
Issues.Body:

This PR is needed to unblock #37798

Issues.Title: Missing pipe not caught by production build with AOT
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description

I have a module with a view that includes a pipe from a library. 
The library was not imported into this module and thus the pipe is not included in the module.
IntelliJ correctly flags the missing pipe but the Angular build process (even when AOT is enabled) does not find this problem

The same issue occurs when referencing a pipe that doesn't even exist at all, the builder never shows any warnings or errors

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7202374/88241836-3cbca700-cc83-11ea-81f9-6cacfa85f183.png)
The above image shows the app component including a pipe that does not exist. The pipe is highlighted red as IntelliJ recognizes the pipe has not been imported. The terminal below shows a successful production build of the project including the missing pipe. I would expect the build to fail

The example above and the repo below are both built using Nrwl NX but the same issue can be found with a regular Angular project

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

Check out the following repo: https://github.com/lukebellamy053/angular-pipe-error-example
Build either of the applications, both should fail as the pipe is either not imported or just doesn't exist but the build passes in both cases

## üî• Exception or Error
There isn't one but there should be
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Missing pipe not caught by production build with AOT" (#18333)

Issues.Title: docs: update release doc to remove outdate information on patch merges
Issues.Body:
Previously instructions for merging to patch instructed caretakers
to only merge commits which were "applicable" to patch.  However,
for PRs targeting master and patch, all commits from the PR should
land in both branches.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "docs: update release doc to remove outdate information on patch merges" (#18332)

Issues.Title: Request upgrade ajv version: Synk Failing - Prototype Pollution - High Severity
Issues.Body:
Currently, we are having some security warning in synk. It's requesting upgrade ajv version of angular-devkit to **6.12.3** from **6.12.0**

Current ajv version
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/d5847623d9ebc7f4f7d116370baf06c74b50e56e/package.json#L126

Error message

@angular-devkit/core@9.0.1
Prototype Pollution [High Severity][https://snyk.io/vuln/SNYK-JS-AJV-584908] in ajv@6.10.2

introduced by @angular-devkit/core@9.0.7 > ajv@6.10.2 and 1 other path(s)

This issue was fixed in versions: 6.12.3
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Request upgrade ajv version: Synk Failing - Prototype Pollution - High Severity" (#18308)

Only meaningful difference with the base PR is that I replaced the nullish coalescing operators with ugly ternaries to be compatible with the older typescript version.

Issues.Title: ci: update release docs to use annotated tags for releases
Issues.Body:
This changes from using lightweight tags to annotated tags. The later includes author, time, and message information that is lacking from the former. It is also included in Git's `--follow-tags` option. This should allow us to push tags alongside release commits more atomically and hopefully eliminate or at least reduce the possibility of a race condition arising from CI starting on the release commit before the associated tag is pushed. Such a state causes CI failures, because they take the latest version from the most recent `v*` tag.

I tested the flow on my local fork, but I can't test a real release unfortunately. I believe our existing infrastructure should "just work", but please let me know if that doesn't appear to be the case.

### Description
angular cli stop publishing lib when the lib is built with prod flag

ngcc will make the build process costing more time than the version before angular 9, especially in the continuous integration env

Issues.Title: build: snapshot builds incorrectly modify semver versions
Issues.Body:
An interesting case that came up in v10.0.0 with the docs-content. The
snapshot release package and docs-content output had various
`@breaking-change` notes in the source code referring to `v10.0.0` as
certain changes are planned to be made at that point.

The snapshot deploy scripts pick up the version from the package.json
file and replace it in the output packages with a more concrete version
that includes the SHA. This meant that we accidentally also overwrote
versions as in the `@breaking-change` notes (ultimately making it
difficult for us to use the latest docs-content for the v10 release as
it was incorrect).

Example snapshot commit: https://github.com/angular/material2-docs-content/commit/e624c7130d90026574b46d12d488e470f0a18c55

We fix this by not including the SHA as part of the deployment, but
rather including the SHA when building the NPM packages. At that point,
we can safely just replace instances of the `0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER` without
having to worry about accidental version overriding.

To achieve this, we update our release stamping script to have two
modes. i.e. snapshot build mode and release mode. Framework does this
by checking the Git tag history but that seems less ideal as it makes
the release output building reliant on external factors while our
stamping is self-contained within the checked out code revision.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: snapshot builds incorrectly modify semver versions" (#20053)

Issues.Title: fix(clipboard): scroll position changing while copying on some browsers
Issues.Body:
The clipboard module works by creating a `textarea` dynamically, focusing it and copying its content. In order to prevent it from affecting the page layout, we put it at `-999em` off-screen, but the problem is that some browsers will try to move it into the view on focus by scrolling up.

These changes use `position: fixed` and anchor the textarea to the top of the page so vertically it's within the viewport.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(clipboard): scroll position changing while copying on some browsers" (#20073)

Issues.Title: feat(drag-drop): cdkConnectedTo finds all drop lists with the same ID, instead of only one
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

`CdkDropList` has `id` and `cdkConnectedTo` input properties to allow specifying an id or array of ids for which the drop lists should be connected.

The `id` input property "needs" to be unique, or better put is "assumed" to be unique - meaning when searching through drop lists to connect to by id, only the first match is returned.

Can the "need" for unique ids be removed and change the connected drop list logic to return **all** drop lists with a matching id?

From the user's perspective:

- If I want a drop list to inherently be standalone, provide a unique id.
- If I want a drop list to inherently be connected to others, provide a shared id.

#### Use Case

Connecting drop lists created dynamically, possibly defined in separate template files and with arbitrary DOM relation, **without** the overhead of having to maintain a separate list of all drop lists that should be connected, and making sure this list is properly updated and propagated to each drop list via change detection.

Instead a statically defined (or could be dynamic) id for the `id` and `cdkConnectedTo` inputs will automatically connect all the drop lists without any further coordination from the user.

Similar to what @sroettering mentioned [here](https://github.com/angular/components/pull/13754#issuecomment-436694651), but I don't think a new input property is necessary.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(drag-drop): cdkConnectedTo finds all drop lists with the same ID, instead of only one" (#20069)

Issues.Title: feat(stepper): Ability to display errors on steps that had no interaction
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

I want to be able to trigger the step error manualy (changing the state of the step).

### Use Case

In a non-linear stepper, I can go to the last step, ignoring some steps (no interaction), and could submit my data even though the form (related with the uninterected step) is invalid.

### Reproduction 
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-cxdumw

1) Click on the 3th step
2) Click on the 4th step
3) Click on Save

#### Current bahavior
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12090931/88175862-d55c1400-cbfc-11ea-9cfa-cabd67ee208d.png)

#### Expected behavior
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12090931/88176058-1fdd9080-cbfd-11ea-9762-cc89a1382877.png)

### Observation
As a workaround to get my desired behavior, you can uncomment the `save()` function content and try the reproduction steps from above again.

`this.matStepper.steps.forEach(x => x.select());`

This way the [interacted property](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/cc1e0fe5964a23eeb4a68e9d090539cb9cdcc04b/tools/public_api_guard/cdk/stepper.d.ts#L15) is set to true, and error state is displayed.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(stepper): Ability to display errors on steps that had no interaction" (#20068)

Issues.Title: build: docs generation script adding extra file extension
Issues.Body:
The `indexFilename` in the `ExampleData` that we were publishing to npm includes the file extension, but because material.angular.io assumes that it's just the filename, we end up adding the extension twice when we generate a Stackblitz example (see https://github.com/angular/material.angular.io/blob/master/src/app/shared/stack-blitz/stack-blitz-writer.ts#L91). This doesn't seem to break the example, but it gets highlighted as invalid in the editor.

The error seems to be a side-effect of d00cb12582ab1265d38bb0f3012b7bd1adced97f where some things were cleaned up. I've fixed the issue by stripping away the extension like before.

Fixes #20061.

Issues.Title: fix(material/progress-spinner): progress-spinners with diameter less than or equal to 10 do not show
Issues.Body:
As @paulferaud  pointed out in #19469, using `BASE_STROKE_WIDTH` when calculating the spinner circle radius is causing issues, such as the progress spinner becoming invisible if the diameter is less than or equal to 10.

The proposed solution is to use the current stroke width instead of the `BASE_STROKE_WIDTH` constant for calculating the spinner radius.

This one change will also stop the spinner circle extending beyond its parent `mat-progress-spinner` dimensions for custom stroke widths (see screenshot and stackblitz below), which I presume is an improvement.

https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-jsceqa?file=src%2Fapp%2Fexample-component.html 

Before commit:
![issue-19469-before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8414922/88111224-728b5e00-cba5-11ea-99fc-8637a2de6da0.png)

After commit:
![issue-19469-after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8414922/88111218-70290400-cba5-11ea-8261-504f83021922.png)


Fixes #19469
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/progress-spinner): progress-spinners with diameter less than or equal to 10 do not show" (#20062)

Issues.Title: coerceBooleanProperty falsy value handling
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a component using a `mat-slide-toggle` with `[checked]="0"` (or any non-boolean falsy value ([reference here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Falsy)) for which the `!= null` check shown below does not pass).

https://github.com/angular/components/blob/4a1b24c42eed23647a65776840ef5f6f83de461e/src/cdk/coercion/boolean-property.ts#L17

#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

The `mat-slide-toggle` should be unchecked.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

The `mat-slide-toggle` is checked.
This leads to awkward code in templates with boolean checks in interpolations not matching the same checks in the `mat-slide-toggle [checked]` input.

#### Environment

- Angular:  `~8.1.1`
- CDK/Material: `~8.1.1`
- Browser(s): Chrome, Firefox
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Linux Mint
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "coerceBooleanProperty falsy value handling" (#20052)

Issues.Title: build: update to latest MDC canary and disable slider
Issues.Body:
Updates to the latest canary version and temporarily disables the MDC-based slider. We have to disable the slider, because MDC have introduced a completely new implementation that will take some work to reintegrate into our current slider and we don't want our CI to fail until then.

I went with this approach of disabling the slider where it's basically a no-op, because we can't simply exclude the build target without modifying a ton of shared files which will be hard to clean up once we start to actually implement it.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: update to latest MDC canary and disable slider" (#20054)

Issues.Title: question(drag-drop): createEmbeddedView for drag preview/placeholder templates
Issues.Body:
A few months back, I opened https://github.com/angular/components/issues/19060 that described a bug with `matchSize` possibly not working correctly due to the preview template being stamped out inside the drop list's view container...and afterward measuring the original drag item.

The solution I proposed in that thread was to just stamp out the preview template view outside of the DOM, so the drop list container children are never touched before being measured.

The fix for this issue was decided to be to measure the original drag item first, then stamp the preview template out in the existing manner in the drop list view container. This works, but the implementation still bugs me because the template is being stamped out in the view container, modifying the DOM, and then the drag preview element is immediately moved to bottom of the document body, modifying the DOM **again** (versus the other solution that only modifies the DOM once). Same idea for the placeholder template as well, how it is placed into the DOM and then immediately moved around (using `replaceChild`)...when it could just be put in the correct place from the start.

@crisbeto made the following comment:
>The idea behind inserting the view through the ViewContainerRef is to ensure that it's inside the same view/DI hierarchy as drag item. I agree that ideally we'd just create the element outside the DOM, but an alternate solution is to measure the element before the preview has been created.

but I am struggling to understand this comment (_"ensure that it's inside the same view/DI hierarchy as drag item"_). As far as I am aware, an injector cannot be specified when using `createEmbeddedView` and the injector used inside the preview template is simply the injector of the component in which the template is **defined**.

Issue about this (still open...) from 3 years ago:
https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/14935

So what would stamping a template out using 
```ts
const viewRef = previewConfig!.viewContainer.createEmbeddedView(previewTemplate, previewConfig!.context);
```
or
```ts
const viewRef = previewTemplate.createEmbeddedView(previewConfig!.context);
```

have anything to do with dependency injection? I feel like the answer is "nothing" but I might be misunderstanding.

@crisbeto can you explain your comment in more detail as to why it is advantageous to use the view container and/or if something I've said above is not accurate?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "question(drag-drop): createEmbeddedView for drag preview/placeholder templates" (#20047)

The API allows to set content on the infoWindow reference by setting content for each marker, so I tried to set the content before I open it but on this component we can only `getContent()` there is no `setContent()` function. Thanks!
